Synthesis of MnO2/CdTiO3 nano‐structure for high performance photocatalysis and antimicrobial application

A MnO2/CdTiO3 is prepared by a simple chemical method. The organic compound such as antibiotics is a contaminant found in large amounts in
pharmaceutical industrial wastewater. Pharmaceutical compounds are toxic.
The nano‐product was characterized by SEM, XRD, XPS, DLS and UV–vis
DRS revealed that the MnO2 nanoparticles were supported on the CdTiO3 surface. The crystallite size was found as 72.11 nm, and 38.13 nm for CdTiO3, and MnCdTi‐1 nanocomposites, respectively. The prepared catalyst was used
for photo‐degradation of cephalexin under UV light irradiation. The result
implies the complete degradation of cephalexin was carried out at 80 min for
MnCdTi‐2 nanocomposites (88.88%) due to this catalyst has the lowest band
gap compared to the other catalyst. The MnO2/CdTiO3 was selected for fungicidal and bactericidal efficiency against Aspergillus flavus, and candida albicans
and Escherichia coli, and Staphylococcus aureus. The MnO2/CdTiO3–2 has great activity is compared with the other MnO2/CdTiO3–0 and MnO2/ CdTiO3–1 samples.
KEYWORDS
biological, cadmium titanate, cephalexin, MnO2, photo‐degradation

sections.heading: 1 | INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The industrial activity exhales the different pollution to air and water.[1,2] These contaminations will be hazardous to the environment. Therefore, the new method was
wileyonlinelibrary.com
designed for the treatment of water. The photocatalytic degradation of pharmaceutical is the novel method for solving the concern about water contaminations.[3,4] Metal oxides such as ZnO, and TiO2 having different properties for photo‐degradation reaction like as light absorption,
© 2019 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd./journal/aoc 1 of 8
charge separation/transformation which that are able to decompose organic compound.[5–9] However, the novel nanomaterials are being applied for the photocatalytic process due to these materials have narrow band gap.[10–16]
The cadmium titanate nanomaterials have various properties in wide application, such as photo‐degradation of many organic compounds.[17–22] Manganese dioxide has fourteen polymorphs[3] and is great nano‐material due to tunnel structures with the cations and can act as host lattices. The photo‐degradation of CdTiO3 can be improved with combine with MoO3 or MnO2 with a decrease in band gap value andmakes the excellent degradation‐process.[22–24]
The CdO + CdTiO3 was synthesized by Sandra Andrea Mayén‐Hernández et al[25] and applied for dye photo‐ degradation. The cadmium titanate was prepared by Saman Rahnamaeiyan et al.[26] and used for degradation of dye. The electrospinning is a new method for synthesis of cadmium titanate nanofibers as photocatalyst and this study was performed by M. Shamshi Hassan al.[27] The MoO3 nanoparticles were prepared by Arumugam Manivel et al.[28] and used for the decomposition of AZO dye. Huabo Yang et al.[29] were investigated on the preparation of MoO3/TiO2 nanocomposites and indicated the enhanced photo‐degradation performance due to combining of two material with together. Hydrothermal technique is a simple method for preparation of MoO3/ Fe2O3/rGO. This project was investigated by R. Balaji Anjaneyulu et al.[30] and the prepared catalyst was used for photo‐degradation of dye. Hao Chen et al.[31] synthesized TiO2–MnO2 nanocomposites for decomposition of organic compound. Vinod Kumar Gupta et al[32] prepared the novel MnO2/NiO nanocomposites as catalyst and carried for photocatalysis and drug delivery studies.
In this project, the new synthesis method was presented to the preparation of MnO2‐CdTiO3 nanocomposites. The novelty of Pechini‐ultrasonic‐hydrothermal method is high in compared to other methods. The great synthesis method includes low cost, consistent and fast. The product of this method has great properties such as chemical stability and great sensitive in UV light and an excellent choice for photo‐degradation system of antibiotic. The other goal of this study is an investigation of other application, anti‐bacterial or antifungal activity. The nanomaterial with eco‐friendly properties has good performance in biological studies.

sections.heading: 2.1 | Materials
sections.text: All In this project, all chemicals were bought from Sigma Aldrich.

sections.heading: 2.2 | Synthesis of nano‐photocatalyst
sections.text:
The cadmium titanate photocatalyst was prepared as a method (Pechini‐ultrasonic‐hydrothermal) from my prior studies.[33]
The Manganese oxide/Cadmium titanate were prepared as this method. Cadmium titanate powders was augmented in 10 ml of C3H6O under ultra‐sonicate irradiation. Then, the MnCl2.4H2O (0.5 M, 50 ml) and the KMnO4 (0.5 M, 50 ml) were propagated to the above suspension, and stirred at 65 °C. Then, NH4OH was augmented to until pH: 7. The product was dried and calcined in oven at 110 °C for 3 hr, and furnace at 450 °C for 4 hr, respectively. The ratio of MnO2 on CdTiO3 nanomaterials was prepared with several samples (0.5:1.0), (1.0:1.0), and (1.0:0.5) and labeled with MnCdTi‐0, MnCdTi‐1, and MnCdTi‐2, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3 | Photo‐decomposition assessment
sections.text: The degradation of cephalexin (CFX, is one antibiotic for a treat of bacterial infections) was investigated by MnO2/ CdTiO3 under UV light with catalyst dose: 0.1 g/l and CFX concentration 25 mg/l, 50 ml in a round bottom flask. To preformation the photo‐bleaching, the mixture was irradiated under UV light (11 W, 254 nm). The CFX solution was stirred for 1 hr in dark to found the adsorption equilibrium of the CFX on the MnO2/CdTiO3 surface. The residual of CFX solution was analyzed with the UV–VIS spectrophotometer at λmax = 274 nm (Perkin Elmer Lambda25). The decomposition performance of the MnO2/CdTiO3 for the CFX removal was determined in the calculation of previous projects.[25]

sections.heading: 2.4 | Characterization of nano‐catalyst
sections.text: The phase purity, band gap of the MnO2/CdTiO3 was investigated by XRD (Philips X'pert Pro) and JASCO V650 UV–Vis‐DRS spectrophotometer, respectively. The morphological, elemental, and surface area data were evaluated by using Carl Zeiss Scanning Electron Microscope, and Quantachrome Nova‐1000 surface analyzer, respectively. Axis Nova spectrometer (Kratos Analytical, Manchester, UK) was employed for the X‐ray photoelectron evaluation. Surface charge of prepared catalyst were studied by using Brookhaven NanoBrook Omni device.

sections.heading: 2.5 | Fungicide and bactericide properties
sections.text:
The disk diffusion method was applied for evaluation of fungicide and bactericide properties with determined the
zones of inhibition (mm). The potato dextrose agar was applied as culture fungal medium. The catalyst doses (1 mM, 50 μL) were poured onto blank disks and incubated at 35 °C in darkness for 72 hrs.[34] The antibacterial properties (inhibition zones) was tested with Mueller Hinton medium was applied as culture Bactria medium (106 CFU/ml). The catalyst doses (1 mM, 50 μL) were poured onto blank disks and incubated at 26 °C for 24 hrs.[34] All these tests were conducted 3 times.

sections.heading: 3 | RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
sections.text:
3.1 | Characterization studies of the nano‐photocatalyst
The UV–visible diffuse reflectance indicates the light response of MnO2/CdTiO3. An excellent nano‐ photocatalyst have a large range of light response such as absorption edge and the intensity in different range. The UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectra are presented in Figure 1. A great absorption intensity in the UV region, which shows the band gap value ascribed to the charge– transfer interaction. In the hybrid materials, the absorption spectrum of the MnO2/CdTiO3 indicated a red shift compared to CdTiO3.The value of the band gap (Eg) determined by the equation of prior project[35] (inset Figure 1). It is obvious with MoO3 doping, the band gap reduced as 2.90, 2.66, 2.57 and 2.35 eV for CdTiO3, MnCdTi‐0, MnCdTi‐1, and MnCdTi‐2, respectively.

The diffracted X‐ray curve in Figure 2 presents the pattern of CdTiO3 and MnO2/CdTiO3–1 nanocomposites. It is obvious, the diffraction peaks of the pure Cadmium titanate demonstrates the orthorhombic phase (JCPDS 29–0277).[33] The peak pattern form MnO2/CdTiO3–1 nanocomposites shows the hexagonal structure of MnO2 (JCPDS 14–644). The average particles of the crystallites nanoparticles (D), calculated by the Scherrer equation,[23,36] are 72.11 nm, and 38.13 nm for CdTiO3 and MnO2/CdTiO3–1 nanocomposites, respectively.
The XPS technique was applied to determine the elemental MnO2/CdTiO3–1 nanocomposites (Figure 3). The result indicates the presence of Cd, Mn, O, and Ti in the hybrid nano‐sample. Cd 3d and Ti 2p in cadmium titanate as doublet peak was located at 400–415 eV (3d5/2: 405.0 eV and 3d3/2: 412.1 eV) and 455–465 eV (2p3/2: 455.2 eV and 2p1/2: 465.2 eV), respectively.
[37] The peak of Ti4+ was observed due to TiO6 octahedra in the CdTiO3 structure.
[37] The Mn 2p3/2 (640.5 eV) and Mn 2p1/2 (653.7 eV) are apperceived and related to MnO2 structure[38] The Oxygen O 1 s peak was apperceived at 529.4 eV.[38]
Figure 4 indicated the FE‐SEM images of the prepared CdTiO3, and MnO2/CdTiO3–1 nanocomposites. From Figure 4A, the MnO2 nanoparticles were prepared and the morphology of these nanoparticles indicates the amorphous particles with low size. It is obvious in Figure 4B, the MnO2 nanoparticles supported on the CdTiO3 and particle size was increased. The agglomeration rate in the hybrid samples was higher than from the MnO2 nanoparticles due to surface charge interaction between the MnO2 and CdTiO3 nanoparticles. The

DLS analysis was shown in Figure 4C. It is obvious, the average particle size of the MnO2 and MnO2/CdTiO3–1 nanocomposites is 40.0, and 50.0 nm, respectively. The BET method was used for evaluation of the active surface area. The specific surface area of MnO2 and MnO2/CdTiO3–1 nanocomposites were 44.56 and 55.89 m2/g, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2 | Photocatalytic study
sections.text:
The plots of Figure 5A actually represent the CFX photo‐ degradation over time in a UV light irradiation. In order to evaluation light sensitivity and equilibrium reaction of CFX photo‐degradation, the process without the catalysts was performed under UV light, and with catalyst was performed under dark media. The high performance of UV light and dark system were 25.14, and 20.55%, respectively. As can be seen, the photocatalytic of CdTiO3 and MnCdTi‐0, MnCdTi‐1, MnCdTi‐2, compared to MoCdTi‐2 nanocomposites. The degradation of CFX was performed for 80 min, and high degradation efficiency was obtained 99.3% for MnCdTi‐2 nanocomposites. The photocatalytic amount of MoCdTi‐2 nanocomposites for removal of CFX in 80 min, is 82.3%.
Figure 5B shows the degradation efficiency for various pH values under 80min. As observed, performance enhances as pH decreases. The highest and lowest performance (98.85% and 24.45%) were found at pH = 4 and 10. The point of zero charge (pHPZC) of MnCdTi‐2 were 3.0 and point of zero charge (pHPZC) of CFX was 4.5. The charge of sample was dependent on pHPZC and the charge in pH > pHPZC and pH ˂ pHPZC are negative and positive, respectively.[39] The charge of prepared catalyst and CFX were negative and positive in pH = 4,
removal of CFX (time: 80 min, nano‐catalyst dose:0.1 g/l) FIGURE 6 (A) Stability graphs of prepared catalyst, and (B) the transient photocurrent responses under UV‐light
respectively. Therefore, the pH = 4 was a great medium for photocatalytic of MnCdTi‐2 nanocomposites for removal of CFX.
The stability of the MnCdTi‐2 were important for their feasible usage. The MnCdTi‐2 photocatalysts were monitored for 5 recycling runs (Figure 6A). After each run, catalyst was separated and dried for the subsequent cycle. The decomposition activity reduced after the 5rd run. The photo‐degradation performance of the MnCdTi‐2 was reduced as 4%. It can be seen, photo stability of MnCdTi‐2 was higher than MnO2 nanoparticles and CdTiO3 nanoparticles.
The photocatalytic mechanism for CFX decomposition by the prepared catalyst was described. The photoexcitation of MnCdTi‐2 catalyst by UV light, generates e− from the VB to the CB of MnCdTi‐2 and the production of h+ in the VB. Next, the induced e− can be transferred from the CB to the mediated state, and react with O2 to generate •O2
− radicals,[40–42] which can make to the CFX degradation. To validation of the complete photo‐ degradation, the transient photocurrent analysis was performed with pure MnCdTi‐2 catalyst and MnCdTi‐2 catalyst after degradation.[37] As observed in Figure 6B, the photocurrent value of MnCdTi‐2 catalyst reduced with the degradation of CFX, presenting the surface of MnCdTi‐2 catalyst was prevented the light absorption and then, the photocurrent value was decreased.

sections.heading: 3.3 | Fungicide and bactericide performance studies
sections.text:
The Fungicide activity of MnCdTi with three ratio was investigated and summarized in Table 1. The MnCdTi‐2 has higher performance (about 16 mm) against Candida albicans, and Trigoderma veride compared with MnCdTi‐0, and MnCdTi‐1.[43] The bactericide activity of MnCdTi with three ratio was studied and summarized in
Table 2. The MnCdTi‐2 was selected as high activity against E. coli and S. aureusin compared to MnCdTi‐0, and MnCdTi‐1 nanocomposites. The activity of surface oxygen species for three catalysts killed the pathogens.[43]

sections.heading: 4 | CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this project, MnO2/CdTiO3 nano‐structure was synthesized by a facile method and demonstrated a great photocatalytic efficiency for the decomposition of cephalexin. The band gap value of the MnO2/CdTiO3 was extremely lowered to compare the CdTiO3 nanoparticles. The band gap were found 2.90, 2.66, 2.57 and 2.35 eV for CdTiO3, MnCdTi‐0, MnCdTi‐1, and MnCdTi‐2, respectively. The degradation of CFX was performed for 80 min and pH: 4, and high degradation efficiency was obtained 99.3% for MnCdTi‐2 nanocomposites. The transition current test demonstrates the photocurrent value of MnO2/ CdTiO3 nano‐structure was decreased after degradation of CFX. The results from biological data revealed the MnO2/CdTiO3 nano‐structure was great for antimicrobial activity.
